title: Domain 2.7: Compare and contrast Internet connection types, network types, and their features.
content:
🌐 Internet Connection Types

🛰️ Satellite

Uses dish antennas to connect to orbiting satellites.
Available almost anywhere, including rural areas.

  • Pros: Wide coverage, doesn’t rely on cable infrastructure
  • Cons: High latency, weather interference

🧠 Tip: Best used where wired options aren't available (rural/farm zones).

🔦 Fiber

Uses light through glass strands to transmit data. Offers very high speed and low latency.

  • Pros: Fastest speeds (up to 10 Gbps+), reliable and secure
  • Cons: Limited availability, costly install

🧠 Tip: Best for high-speed or business-class connections.

📺 Cable

Uses coaxial cable (same as cable TV). Common in residential broadband.

  • Pros: Widely available, fast downloads
  • Cons: Shared bandwidth, slower uploads

🧠 Tip: Key word: “coax” or “splitter” = cable connection.

☎️ DSL (Digital Subscriber Line)

Uses existing telephone lines. Always-on connection, unlike dial-up.

  • Pros: Affordable, widely available
  • Cons: Speed drops with distance, slower than cable/fiber

🧠 Tip: DSL = step up from dial-up, down from cable/fiber.

📱 Cellular

Uses mobile networks (3G/4G/5G). Good for mobile and backup connections.

  • Pros: Mobile, flexible, backup-ready
  • Cons: Data caps, variable coverage

🧠 Tip: Mentions of SIM card, LTE, or hotspot = cellular.

🌐 WISP (Wireless Internet Service Provider)

Uses radio signals from towers for internet. Common in rural areas.

  • Pros: Doesn’t need cables, faster than satellite
  • Cons: Requires line-of-sight, weather/terrain interference

🧠 Tip: “Rural area, tower on roof, no cable/fiber” → WISP.

🌐 Network Types

🏠 LAN (Local Area Network)

Covers a small area like a home, office, or school. Uses Ethernet or Wi-Fi.

🧠 Tip: Network within one physical site = LAN.

🌍 WAN (Wide Area Network)

Connects multiple LANs across large areas. Uses public/leased infrastructure.

🧠 Examples: Internet, multi-site business networks.

👤 PAN (Personal Area Network)

Very short range (a few meters). Connects personal devices like:

  • Smartphones
  • Smartwatches
  • Bluetooth keyboards/headsets

🧠 Tip: PAN = “your body bubble” network.

🏙️ MAN (Metropolitan Area Network)

Spans a city or large campus. Often run by governments or ISPs.

🧠 Tip: Used in universities, business parks, city infrastructure.

💾 SAN (Storage Area Network)

High-speed block-level storage network. Used in enterprise and data centers.

🧠 Tip: SAN = network of storage devices, separate from user LANs.

📶 WLAN (Wireless LAN)

A LAN using Wi-Fi. Gives wireless access to local network resources.

🧠 Tip: SSID, access points, WPA2 security = WLAN features.
